captions.text: Good morning, John; it's Friday.

A few weeks ago a company called Visually
emailed me, and was like "Hey Hank. If you

could do a high-quality, animated video on
any issue in the world, what would you choose?".

Now that was a hard choice, but I went with
incarceration in America, because it is messed
up.

Now, crime is also messed up; bad things happen
to good people, and that's terrible, and something

should be done about it. Well, we send people
to prison to be punished, and to prevent them

from doing bad things again, and to deter
others from breaking the law. Punishment,
corrections, and deterrence.

Now we have this habit of thinking of prisoners
as something very external to society; after

all, there are literal walls between them
and society: walls capped with razor wire

and watched over by people with guns. But
millions of prisoners are released each year

- today's prisoners are tomorrow's neighbors.
So corrections should probably be the most

important piece of the incarceration pie.
Unfortunately, it is not.

We are, however, really good at punishment.
America has about 4% of the world's people

and about 25% of the world's incarcerated
people. We have the highest incarceration

rate in the world. Over the last 30 years,
that number has skyrocketed, increasing over

41% of American juveniles and young adults
have been arrested by the time they turn 23.

Children as young as 13 years old have been
sentenced to die in prison, and our prisons
violate international standards.

Solitary confinement increases instability
and violence in inmates, and is considered

by international law to be torture, but in
America, it's not regulated by anyone except

the prison officials; no judge, no jury. Arguably
the most devastating form of punishment we

enact in this country, and yet there is no
appeals process.

And you think it's hard to get a job in America?
Well, we make it intentionally more difficult

to get a job once you have a conviction on
your record, not to mention just live your

life. Convicts are ineligible for welfare,
student loans, public housing, food stamps,

and are often socially disconnected from community
and family support structures. So in addition

to have high recidivism rates, they have very
high rates of homelessness and suicide.

Somewhere along the way, we started to think
that being tough on crime meant being tough

on criminals. But that's not the same thing.
Punishment is only one piece of a much larger

crime reduction pie, and it's an expensive
one; with some institutions paying more than
$100,000 per year per prisoner.

Long prison sentences have helped to decrease
crime, but no more than 25% of the decrease

that we've seen can be attributed to incarceration,
and it costs far beyond just dollars: the

cost is to people, to our country, to communities,
to families, and to ourselves. The policy

seems to be, if you've committed a felony,
we just give up on you.

These wars on crime, wars on drugs, they are
wars on people; the smart political move is

to appear tough on crime because crime is
scary, so we increased minimum sentences,

we arrested more people, we sent more of them
to prison. That's how we looked tough on crime,
but the results are in: it's bad policy!

It's cruel, it's shortsighted, and to continue
this policy of mass incarceration would be

foolish. We're living inside of a massive
$75 billion per year failed experiment. 2010

was the first year in nearly 40 years that
the number of incarcerated individuals in
America did not increase.

Policy makers are beginning to realize the
magnitude of this failure, but there is a
long way to go.
John, I'll see you on Tuesday.

Okay so basically, in my own words to hopefully help people understand is 
this:

Let's say you commit a crime and are put in jail for five years. This time 
is your punishment for committing whatever crime you have been put in jail 
for.
So, after you've finished the punishment, you are let out of jail, but your 
punishment isn't really over, because now you can't get a job, and the 
public views you as "scary". You've been in prison for five years, but now 
you may have to live on the streets, anyway. Your life isn't, and may never 
get back on track.
You're punishment should be over after you serve your time in jail. It's 
not. You are still being punished and will keep being punished for a long 
time.

This is a screwed up system.﻿

comments.text:
I agree 100%. I have actually been thinking about this lately, on a 
philosophical level. Like, if you believe everything you ever do is a 
product of either your biology or your environment, it makes it difficult 
to put blame on people for their actions. I mean I totally get why feeling 
responsible for your actions is really really important, but on a deeper 
level, it doesn't seem like we are.
Consider how sentencing works. Some people who plead guilty can get a lower 
sentence or avoid jail by pleading insanity. The Boston Bomber lawyers are 
trying to spare his life by claiming that Dzhokhar Tsarnaev's was under the 
influence of his brother. People get less severe punishments if they can 
prove that factors beyond their control effected their decisions, but what 
if all the factors that affect what we do are beyond our control?
After thinking about this for a while, I feel like prisons should focus 
completely on rehabilitation, and protecting society, and completely throw 
out punishment for the sake of punishment.﻿

*You failed to mention the simple fact that private prisons create an 
incentive for very powerful people to help incarcerate as many people as 
possible.* There have been multiple recorded occurrences of contracts 
between private prison companies and American states containing clauses 
guaranteeing a given occupancy rate, sometimes as high as 90%. Meaning if 
the prisons aren't at 90% capacity by the deadline, the state has to pay 
for the unused beds or find more people to incarcerate. Private prisons are 
huge business in the US, and lobbying by private prison companies is one of 
the biggest reasons why sentences for non violent crimes are maintained so 
high. The fact you didn't mention that seems completely backwards to me,

comments.text:
This video gives a very simplistic view of the situation. It's true that 
the US has much more incarcerated people on average than the "world at 
large" but it's also true that much more people OUGHT TO BE INCARCERATED IN 
THE REST OF THE WORLD. The problem with his comparison is that it is the US 
versus the World - some places in the world will vastly skew the numbers as 
a result because lawlessness is OUT OF CONTROL there. Significant examples? 
Mexico, India, many nations in Africa, the Middle East (how about the 
thousands of criminals in Al Queda, Hamas and IS), South America (Brazil is 
an easy eg.) and South East Asia. Some are worse than others obviously. 
Incredible lawlessness in the corrupt government itself is a problem in 
many of those countries which is why lawlessness in the country outside 
government is severe.

The fact is, we've decreased crime tremendously and people don't get away 
with crime in the US NO WHERE NEAR as they could have 20-30 years ago. If 
you murder someone, with enough time (usually a 48hr limit for detectives), 
they will find you. Explanations for increased incarceration? Improved 
crime investigation science (DNA, face identification software from videos 
individuals etc) and government surveillance (technology etc).

If anything, increased incarceration is a news flash to many people that 
"humanity" is not as "good" as they wish it was.

If they want something to compare the US to, it must be a nation of similar 
size and of similar resources to sustain law enforcement. Maybe one could 
compare it to certain European Nations (or Australia) or multiple ones. 
Perhaps you should have a resource to size ratio. Many, many factors ought 
to be considered beyond this poor explanation. I'm not educated in this 
political field but being a science major, well read on history and 
traveler to international places, this video is obviously wrong to some 
extent. Shame on them for such a poor comparison. Hank is smarter than this﻿

 Show them what they are doing to their victims.  empathy is a powerful

comments.author: Adam Satchwell

comments.text:
+Adam Satchwell no.  i won't spit statistics your way because there are far 
too many involved for a simple Youtube debate.  which has been my point. 
 you can NOT just look at 1 or 2 statistics and use them as evidence that 
an entire system is flawed.  There are simply too many factors involved to 
make such a stupid accusation.  

I will explain what i mean in an easier to understand example.  

Imagine a police officer is assigned a territory in a major city to patrol. 
 that officer makes arrests, and gives traffic tickets on a daily basis. 
 One day, the police commissioner looks at this officers records and 
notices that 80% of his arrests and tickets have been to black people. 
 Using that statistic, he calls the officer in to his office, accuses him 
of racism, and fires the officer.  Does that seem fair?  Afterall, the 
statistics clearly show the officer arrests FAR more black people than 
white, in a city where the population is 60% white, 15% black, 15% latino 
and 20% other races.  Seems like an open and shut case of racism to most 
people.  The statistics don't lie right?  Except that there is more to 
consider.  the fact that the officer was assigned a territory for example, 
so he was unable to make arrests anywhere outside of that territory, and 
the fact that while the entire city has a black population of only 15%, 
that specific area the officer was assigned to had housing projects which 
housed 70% of the black people in the city.  So the cop was just doing his 
job in an area that was almost 3/4 black people, making it obvious that 
most of his arrests would be on black people.  

So as you can see, listing of 1 or 2 or even 3 statistics and using them to 
form a wide sweeping conclusion about something as complicated as the 
justice and punishment system of an entire country, is STUPID at best.

I never said there was something wrong with American culture, society, or 
anything of the sort.  I simply said there are differences between 
countries, with no mention of one being better or worse than others.  You 
are trying to straw man me.  

i also did not say that American culture creates more criminals that other 
countries.  I was pointing out how the differences in cultures can lead to 
higher incarceration rates, based on things like what laws people are 
jailed for in countries.  I gave the example of Singapore.  Instead of 
sending people to prison, they whip them with a cane.  If Singapore did not 
whip people, but sent them to jail, their incarceration rate would likely 
match or exceed that of the US.  There are also things like the US will 
jail a person for possession of marijuana, increasing the incarceration 
rate more than countries that do not send people to jail for the same 
crime.  With marijuana use widespread throughout the world, that alone is a 
huge difference in incarceration rates.  and by cultural differences, i did 
not mean America as a whole, but rather the smaller individual cultures 
that exist within America.  Black culture in the inner city project housing 
is notorious for breeding criminals.  Latino culture in the southwest leads 
to other sorts of crimes simply because what they were doing was legal in 
mexico, but not legal in the US, and also because some latino cultures do 
not get along with other latino cultures, leading to confrontations.  there 
are also white cultures that have their share of issues as well. 

I bet you would be surprised to learn that as a whole, the US has a lower 
overall crime rate than Britain.  

And don't be stupid.  There are humane and inhumane ways of executing a 
person.  It can either be over quickly and painlessly, or it can take time 
and be excruciatingly painful. 

As far as rehab, i have already stated my position on this.  If you want 
rehab, then do it separately from the punishment.  the very reason the US 
has a higher re-offender rate is BECAUSE for the last 50+ years the US has 
been trying to force rehabilitation into the prison system, and every year 
the numbers get worse.  The prison system and the rehabilitation system 
have to be two different entities in order to work properly.  

Charles Manson and Jeffery Dhalmer are not sick.  they are evil.  I know it 
must seem like they must be mentally ill in order to do the things they 
did, but that is not the case.  they are just bad people.   And even if 
they were sick, SO WHAT?  Of what benefit is it to ANYBODY to keep them 
alive?  they aren't going to ever not be sick, they will always be 
murderers.  If you can't reconcile with executing somebody who has killed 
20+ people and would do it again, then how could you reconcile locking them 
in prison for their entire lives?  Either way it is punishing the sick is 
it not?

I would rather live in a world where criminals are punished for their 
crimes, and once they accept and serve their sentence, they can choose 
themselves to go into rehab to better their lives.  But under no 
circumstances would i condone a system that rewards a person with a 
comfortable place to live, free of charge, and works to improve their 
lives, all because they killed or raped or otherwise infringed on the 
rights of another human being.
comments.author: Kur Norock

comments.author: Adam Satchwell

comments.text:
+Adam Satchwell
incarceration rates and conviction rates are entirely different things. 
 Japan currently has a 99% conviction rate while the US has a 95% 
conviction rate.  This just means that more people who deserve punishment, 
whether that be jail time, community service, or just a fine, are getting 
punishment.  Incarceration rates are the number of people who are actually 
sent to prison.  so yes, i was right about conviction rates. 

As far as incarceration rates go, you can't just look at one statistic and 
say "well there's your problem!".  countries are different.  Different 
cultures, different laws, and different ways of dealing with things.  Much 
of the US prosecutes and sends people to jail for buying, using, or selling 
marijuana.  It is illegal.  But other countries do not.  That will affect 
incarceration rates.  In Singapore the incarceration rate is 1/3 that of 
the US, but they also beat people with a cane rather than send them to 
prison, which in the US would be unconstitutional.  I imagine if we used 
caning as punishment for our lesser crimes, our incarceration rate would be 
much lower.  Comparing countries on this ONE statistic and using it to say 
one country is better or worse than another is fundamentally stupid.  

about re-offending rates..  allow me to clarify my statement.  "*With all 
else being equal*, 1st world countries with comfy prisons will have higher 
re-offending rates."  But as i just pointed out, all else is not equal. 
 There are other considerations to take into account.  the nature of the 
crimes being committed (for example, bicycle theft is MUCH more rampant in 
England than the US) time served for specific crimes, even the culture of 
the people committing the crimes (much more peer pressure to re-offend in 
some cultures) and any number of other factors.  All of which can be 
deterred with harsher conditions in prison facilities.  

I did not argue about the death penalty. I argued about cushy prison 
conditions.  there is a HUGE difference between living in uncomfortable 
conditions and being forced to work hard manual labor for 20 years, vs 
living is relative comfort for 10-15 years then being humanely executed at 
the end of it.  Also, the death penalty is not used in every case of 
murder, only the more severe cases.  Most murders are a crime of passion, 
unplanned and committed in the heat of the moment with no time to think of 
consequences.  Personally i am not a huge fan of the death penalty, only 
because on occasion an innocent person can be executed.  but for somebody 
like Charles Manson, or Jeffry Dhalmer?  What purpose is there is letting 
somebody like that continue to live? 

And i agree.  the US spends too much on prisoners.  

Yes, as i've pointed out already, there are differences between people in 
Norway and the US, cultural, geographical, political, social, and economic 
differences.  Not to mention things that always contribute to crimes rates 
such as population density.  Countries are different.  

Explain how a cushy life in prison equates to lower re-offender rates. 
 Don't just spit statistics that fit your preconceived notions either, 
actually explain the process.
comments.author: Kur Norock

comments.text:
+Kur Norock

You claim that first world countries will have higher conviction rates due 
to having less corruption/better policing but this is just wrong. Iceland, 
Japan and Denmark are all first world countries but per 100000 only 44, 63 
and 66 people are incarcerated respectively. In the USA it is 753 per 
100000. 


The top ten reoffending countries list includes USA, Rwanda, Belize, 
Khazakstan, Cuba and Russia. So yeah, your wrong that first would countries 
will just naturally have higher crime rates, it seems to actually be the 
opposite. 


Also your idea that when people know they will be punished they are less 
likely to commit a crime is wrong. For example in America states with the 
death penalty have 18% higher murder rates than states without the death 
penalty. 


Also, you claim that for every one reoffender there are 'dozens of people 
who never have to go back' but this is just wrong. Statistics suggest 
between 60-70% of prisoners in America reoffend. So actually for every 3 
people who never go back there are 7 people who do. 


Also your idea that harsher prison conditions will result in fewer people 
'wanting' to go to jail is wrong. In Norway an average of 283 Euros is 
spent on each prisoner per day, more than America, and prisoners enjoy 
greater comfort, food, conditions and amenities, there is no death penalty, 
no solitary confinement and no life imprisonment, with I believe a maximum 
sentence is 21 years (from memory might be wrong.) Yet the conviction rate 
is only 70 per 100000, compared to Americas 753 per 100000.


The American system is also costly, it costs on average 117 Euros per 
prisoner per day in the England, where reoffender rates are at 50%, 
compared to 259 Euros per prisoner per day in the USA, where reoffender 
rates are at 70%. So you spend of twice as much per prisoner and have an 
extra 20% reoffend, winning. 



In Norway statistics suggest that only 20-30% of prisoners reoffend, and 
only 70 per 100000 are incarcerated. Compare this to Americas 70% 
reoffender rate and 753 per 100000 incarcerated. 


So do you think there is some innate difference between Americans and 
Norwegians that just makes Americans more likely to commit crime and 
reoffend? Or do you think the way Norway deals with crime and punishment 
might be the reason why so few reoffend?


If you want a suggest for how the number of incarcerated and reoffender 
rates could be reduced have a google into how Norwegians treat their 
prisoners. I suspect you wont be a fan, despite the fact that all the 
evidence suggest the Norwegian is better. Probably because you like having 
angry negative thoughts about prisoners because it makes you feel more 
secure in your angry little oh no my street is closed world. 


So: Americas system is costly, has the highest prison population, doesn't 
act as deterrent and has one of the worst reoffender rates= failed policy, 
Or Americas are naturally criminals. Somehow I blame the failed policy.

comments.text:
This is a valid philosophical conclusion if you subscribe to determinism. 
The argument goes, if our choices are decided by our genes and external 
stimuli alone, then those that commit crime are the victims of 
circumstance. A deterministic theory reduces the purpose of the criminal 
justice into two parts rather than the video's three: deterrent and public 
protection. I and many others agree with this and I think it's a much more 
helpful way of viewing the world.

+McZidanne While it's easy to understand why the gut-reaction for victims 
or the loved ones of victims is anger, I will never understand those who 
genuinely believe that kind of righteous anger is what should guide our 
justice system. The aim should always be to create a better society with 
less crime and it has been proven over and over again that the best way to 
do that is to humanize and care for the people who commit crimes because 
more often then not, criminals are disenfranchised individuals who have 
become detached from society through poverty, mental illness, addiction or 
trauma. Showing them that society cares and that there is a place for them 
in it through compassion will do more to keep them from committing further 
crime than any punishment ever could. It's late, I'm starting to ramble, I 
think I'll stop now.

comments.text:
The "Vast majority" of the people are in for non-violent, non-victim 
"crimes" that would be otherwise either disregarded or incur a small 
fine/community service. Also society kind of provokes criminal activities. 
A shitty job market and a shitty economy leads to income issues which bring 
up problems individuals experience and serves to only excacerbate such 
issues. This is where people get desperate. I'm sure a society that doesn't 
regard human life as "disposable" doesn't really have "Crime" problems to a 
large scale. Also there are some 2-3 million Americans in jail (e.g. 
imagine the city of Denver becoming a prison camp) and how many of those 
are actually "criminals"? Probably no more than 100,000 but that is just 
speculation
